oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville Board of Commissioners

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Rosecrans, William S. (William Starke), 1819-1898; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Driver, William K.; Nashville (Tenn.); Military orders; Nashville Board of Claims; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Claims
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Headquarters Dept of the Cumberland Murfreesboro Tenn Mar 13th 1863 Special Field orders ) No 69. ) ) X X X X III A Board of Commissioners consisting of three Citizens and two Officers is hereby appointed to investigate and report upon the damage sustained by the Citizens of Nashville and vicinity from the occupation of the place by Military Forces of the United States. Detail for the Board. Hon Russell Houston Horace H. Harrison Esq Capt A D. Vanasdal 3rd I. Cavly Wm. Driver Esq. Capt S F Allen 29th Ind. Vol. The Board will meet on Monday next mar 16th at 10.o’clk am. At such place in the City of Nashville as they select and all claims for the year ending Decr. 31st 1862 must be presented before April 1st 1863. X X X By Command of Major Genl. Rosecrans S. Terall Capt and AAG. A true copy Silas F. Allen Capt 29th Ind Vol Infty.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Special Field Order No. 69 from Headquarters, Department of the Cumberland, calling for creation of a commission to investigate damages sustained by Nashville citizens and their property during Federal occupation.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- War Dept. -- Adjutant-General's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society Civil War Collection, 1860-1982
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fort Donelson fell on February 16, 1862, and Federal occupation of Nashville soon followed, as the Federal Army of Don Carlos Buell marched into the city. At the end of that month, Nashville became the first state capital to fall to the Federal troops. Confederate uprisings and guerrilla attacks continued sporadically against the city, but had little effect overall. The amount claimed to this Nashville Board of Commissioners was over $2.6 million. The amount awarded for damages was over $1 million.
